comment: probably the worst course i have ever taken at KSU. matt is sometimes tolerable to be around and can make for great conversations but is very clearly full of himself and cares more about his own work than students'. it was a nightmare to go to his class every week. very harsh grader with little feedback. loves pretentious stuff

Please do yourself a favor and do not take this Professor. He has no business being a professor. He almost most every project he has add up my project grade wrong. He only wants you to do work that he interested in. Art is subjective, but he is so egotistical. You will also basically be teaching yourself. Feedback is vague.

really enjoyed this class. Haffner doesn't hold your hand though. starts projects with a presentation and from there its an amazing race style studio time. plenty of running around campus scavenging for cardboard and plastic and fun materials. not time to think, go on instinct kind of class. super fun, super difficult, but when it works it works.

Passed the class but only because I followed the professors projects word for word. Its a creativity class and there was no creativity in any of the projects we had to do unless you wanted a bad grade. Take him if you want a challenge.

for film photography  He is a great teacher and super engaging. However, he does except a lot of time and work to go into the class. May be hard to do if you work and have more then one other class. I had to take off work & such to finish projects & found myself not liking the class. However, you do learn a lot. Attendance is important too.

Super cool guy. Critiques are interesting and projects are usually pretty fun. Doesn't give a lot of time on bigger projects, though (have cried about his class). Doesn't appreciate the cliche and wants you to really think outside the box. Hard class, but overall fun for what it is.

I took this class during a 4 week session in summer - I was a bit apprehensive about the pace at first (quick!), however I enjoyed the material and stayed on top of the assignments and deadlines. He is very straightforward about participation and passionate about learning the material and concepts. Great professor - I definitely recommend!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: Easy class, We have 14 discussions but only 8 are graded. 3 tests easy, use your **resources**, and one paper about art. Easiest A I ever took.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Graded by few things--Clear grading criteria

comment: Although art is subjective, I feel like this class is more about what he likes. He wants you to push yourself to try new medias, so don't create anything cliche. He offers some extra credit by visiting art galleries and writing about them. He also grades at the very last minute. Theres art critiques and he changes the grading criteria frequently.

Honestly such a great professor. 14 discussion modules available, 8 had to be submitted. 150-200 words each 3 tests and a museum analysis. Read the book and you're guaranteed to get an A in the class.

This class is a good bit of work, but you learn so much and it's fun. You'll learn the exposure triangle, as well as how to develop film and print in the darkroom. You get to borrow cameras from the school, but if you have an old film camera you can use it too.

This is a good class for any art major to take because every artist should at least know how to photograph their own work. It's not as expensive as some make it seem, if you cut your mat boards nicely the first critique, then you can reuse them for the entire semester. The assignments are fun to do, and Matt helps guide you along the way. Show up!

There's a weekly photo assignment that he gives you a prompt for. It's fun to see what everyone uploads and takes the place of a discussion board basically. I took this class in person, however I think it is now only offered online. It's not that hard as long as you do the readings and take good notes for each lecture.

These reviews are absolutely hilarious.  Anyone who has studied under Matt for an extended amount of time knows how much he has to offer as both a professor and working artist.  He really just wants to see his students create the best quality of work possible.  If you expect an 'A' for mediocre work, you will be sorely disappointed.

I've had him for a variety of classes including History of Photo and studio classes. I really enjoy him as a professor. He is extremely helpful and always willing to give technical or conceptual advice. He can be hard to please, but when you get a good grade, it's a big boost. He's open minded and sees the value of hard work within his students.

I'm terrible at any and all history classes and he made this more interesting than a normal art history course. He does teach from powerpoints but made lectures bearable and humorous. Quizzes from reading are TOUGH! We had a take home midterm and open note final but I don't think he'll be doing either of those again.
He picks favorites... and they make an A. and Concept is the world to him.

Incredibly tough, for no good reason. Incredibly expensive, again for no good reason. Matt has lackluster technical skills and even worse teaching skills.  You'll spend A TON of $$ to print absurd amounts of work instead of focusing time and money on worth while pieces.  Prefers quantity to quality.
matt is the worst teacher ever. all he does is take pictures of himself and if you dont take pictures just like him he points out to the class that you will never be famous like him.
He IS the worst egotist and he has no business being one. Look at his work first and then decide...Ugh.

I didn't like him at first, but he really is an excellent professor. He might seem egotistic and arrogant, but he really isn't. Very helpful, creative, and knowledgable. I've really enjoyed his class.
His ego is nauseating. AVOID HIM! Wait for Prof. Dibble instead.
